title: Supply-Chain Obstacles Led to Last Month's Cut to Pfizer's Covid-19 Vaccine-Rollout Target
summary: Pharma giant found raw materials in early production didn't meet its standards. When Pfizer Inc. said last month it expected to ship half the Covid-19 vaccines it had originally planned for this year, the decision highlighted the challenges drug makers face in rapidly building supply chains to meet the high demand.

title: Senate Passes Bill to Clear Green-Card Backlog for Indian Immigrants
summary: Legislation differs from House version, leaving prospects of new law unclear. WASHINGTON-The Senate unanimously passed a bill late Wednesday aimed at clearing a backlog of green cards for primarily Indian immigrants, after more than a year of wrangling following House passage of a similar bill in 2019.

title: OPEC, Allies Agree to Increase Output by 500,000 Barrels a Day
summary: Deal ends standoff and promises modest boost to global supplies as markets tighten. OPEC and a group of Russia-led oil producers agreed to increase their collective output by 500,000 barrels a day next month, signaling the world's biggest producers are betting the worst of a pandemic-inspired shock to demand is behind them.

title: DOJ Sues Facebook Over H-1B Visas
summary: Justice Department lawsuit says social-media company didn't sufficiently advertise open positions, overlooked U.S. residents. The Trump administration has sued Facebook Inc. , accusing the social-media company of illegally reserving high-paying jobs for immigrant workers it was sponsoring for permanent residence, rather than searching adequately for available U.S. workers who could fill the positions.

title: Buyout Firm Thomas H. Lee Partners Refinances Investment in Hightower
summary: Goldman Sachs, Neuberger Berman and Coller Capital are investing in a secondary deal that extends THL's time as the wealth manager's principal backer. Thomas H. Lee Partners has bought itself more time to manage an investment in wealth-advisory firm Hightower Advisors LLC through a secondary transaction with investors that include Goldman Sachs Group Inc.

title: Trump and the Georgia Runoffs
summary: The President will get the blame if the GOP loses the Senate.. The most important story in politics for the next month isn't the foregone outcome of the presidential race. It's the two Georgia runoff races on Jan. 5 that will determine who controls the Senate and the direction of U.S. policy for the next two years. If Republicans lose those seats, President Trump will be the main reason, and the main casualty will be his legacy.

title: The Biden Terrorism Account
summary: Small investments help prevent major distractions later on.. Two decades after 9/11, Washington understandably is concerned more with great-power competition than terrorism. But a new report from the Institute for Economics & Peace (IEP) is a reminder that terror groups remain a global scourge.

title: The FDA's Political Inoculation
summary: Why the U.K. has approved a vaccine faster than the U.S.. The U.K. on Wednesday approved Pfizer -BioNTech's vaccine, and no doubt many Americans are wondering as thousands die each day why the U.S. Food and Drug Administration wasn't first. Blame politicians who promoted public skepticism of a vaccine that U.S. regulators now feel they must remedy.

title: Covid-19 Hits Buffalo, N.Y., Much Harder Than in Spring
summary: Officials aiming to avoid lockdown warn residents, 'Don't invite people over to watch the Bills game'. Public-health officials in Buffalo, New York's second-most populous city, are fighting a surge in coronavirus cases with the normal calls for residents to avoid social gatherings and wear masks in public.

title: Five Current and Former MTA Employees Charged with Overtime Fraud
summary: One worker claimed more than $300,000 in overtime in one year. Five current and former New York Metropolitan Transportation Authority workers have been charged with falsely claiming hundreds of hours of overtime pay.

title: U.S. Boosts China Spying Budget to Meet Growing National-Security Threat
summary: Director of national intelligence said shift involves 'money and manpower,' and suggested some analysts focused on counterterrorism would be refocused on Beijing. WASHINGTON-The U.S. is increasing the portion of the spying budget devoted to China by nearly one-fifth this year, U.S. officials said on Thursday, reflecting rising concern over what the Trump administration says is a top economic, security and counterintelligence threat from Beijing.

title: South Carolina Utility Agrees to $137.5 Million Settlement
summary: SEC charged Scana and a subsidiary with misleading investors after a $9 billion nuclear power plant expansion was canceled. Scana Corp. and a subsidiary agreed to a $137.5 million settlement to resolve civil-fraud charges related to a failed nuclear power plant expansion, federal prosecutors said Thursday.

title: McConnell's Spending Line
summary: Can he hold it? The answer will set the course of Biden's presidency.. Joe Biden isn't yet in the White House, but we are about to witness a crucial test of his ability to roll a closely divided Senate. Republicans can hold the line on Covid relief, or a divided GOP can signal that Biden Democrats will hold the whip hand on spending.

title: Macron Seeks an Enlightened Islam
summary: Laïcité worked well with Catholicism, but how hard is it to tame a domestic religion?. Emmanuel Macron has resolved to be the president who finally eases tensions over France's young and growing Muslim population. Every president since Valéry Giscard d'Estaing in the 1970s has resolved to do that. None succeeded, and the stakes have risen with each failure.

title: International Oil Benchmark Weighs Adding U.S. Crude to Mix
summary: The widely followed Brent gauge could get a makeover to include prices for Texas crude, highlighting the importance of U.S. exports. Brent crude, the international gauge for oil prices, may be overhauled to reflect the growing importance of U.S. exports in global energy markets.

title: Unemployment Bonus Proves Its Harm
summary: Job openings declined sharply in August, after the $600 weekly payments stopped.. Congressional Democrats and some Republicans are frantically trying to stitch together another $1 trillion "stimulus" bill. Why? The economy and jobs market have far exceeded expectations of recovery even without the spending spree first proposed by Speaker Nancy Pelosi in July.

title: 'The National Baseball Hall of Fame Collection' Review: A Choice of Players
summary: An oversize, lavishly illustrated celebration of America's favorite trading-card icons and the shrine created for them in Cooperstown, N.Y.. A quotation often trotted out this time of year comes from Baseball Hall of Famer Rogers Hornsby, who played in his last game in 1937: "People ask me what I do in winter when there's no baseball. I'll tell you what I do. I stare out the window and wait for spring."

title: Software Ate the World, and Soon It Will Write Itself
summary: Developers are in short supply, but their products may acquire the capacity to replace them.. 'Software is eating the world," tech investor Marc Andreessenobserved in these pages in 2011. Now software is writing itself.

title: Notable & Quotable: Harvard Law Review
summary: 'The second way to pursue a fairer Senate apportionment would be simply to ignore the constitutional provision mandating two senators for every state.'. Harvard law professor Michael J. Klarman writing in the November 2020 Harvard Law Review:

title: Data Science Focus Delivers for Pitney Bowes
summary: Shipping services firm plans to ramp up AI used to help automate a growing e-commerce business. Pitney Bowes Inc.'s expansion into software-powered logistics has helped the century-old company capture a piece of a booming e-commerce market sparked by the coronavirus outbreak, the company's chief innovation officer says.

title: Senate Confirms Fed Economist Waller to Board Seat
summary: Confirmation secured with fewer votes for any Fed governor since at least 1980. The Senate confirmed one of President Trump's picks Thursday to a vacancy on the Federal Reserve's board of governors in a vote that reflected increased partisan tensions over issues related to the looming change in presidential administrations.

title: Energy Trader Vitol Paying $163 Million to Settle Charges
summary: Company accused of using bribes to gain advantage when bidding for oil in Brazil, Mexico, Ecuador. Swiss-based energy firm Vitol agreed to pay $163 million to settle criminal and civil charges that its employees paid bribes to gain an advantage when bidding for oil in Brazil, Mexico and Ecuador.

title: HBO Max Needs the Kick From Warner's Flicks
summary: First-run movies may help overcome confusing strategy that has limited adoption of the stand-alone streaming service. WarnerMedia might still need movie theaters. For now, though, it needs HBO Max even more.

title: Walmart, Like Amazon, to Pay U.S. Workers Holiday Bonuses
summary: Retailers make special payments during pandemic as they battle for staff during peak season. Walmart Inc. said it would pay another round of bonuses to U.S. workers as the retailer, like rival Amazon.com Inc., seeks to retain and reward staffers managing a surge in sales during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Capital One CFO to Leave for Health-Insurance Startup
summary: Financial holding company names the finance chief of its business segments as successor. Capital One Financial Corp.'s finance chief is leaving the bank to take over the finance department at Oscar Health Insurance Corp., an insurance startup.

title: Treasury Volatility Boosts Tradeweb
summary: Volatility and remote trading fueled near-record November; market share of corporate trading crossed 10% threshold. Sharp moves in Treasury bonds have whipsawed investors recently, but the volatility has made a winner out of Tradeweb Markets Inc., a large electronic marketplace for U.S. government debt.

title: Fitness Platform Obé Rolls Out Workout Parties for Remote Friends
summary: New feature comes as the fitness industry heads toward its usual winter bump. Obé Fitness, an at-home workout platform offering live-streamed and on-demand health classes, is rolling out a feature to let subscribers exercise remotely with up to seven friends at once.

title: Sean Patrick Maloney Wins Race to Head House Democrats' Political Arm
summary: The representative from New York campaigned on courting voters whom the party failed to reach in the 2020 cycle. WASHINGTON-House Democrats selected New York Rep. Sean Patrick Maloney to lead the caucus through its next campaign cycle, choosing a chairman who represents the types of districts the party will need to win to expand its narrow majority.

title: Is Land Rover's New Defender SUV More Trouble Than It's Worth?
summary: With overlanding power and a three-foot wading depth, the handsome Defender can conquer the Andes. But the brand has well-documented reliability issues. Dan Neil on whether the benefits outweigh the risks. BY THIS TIME in a normal year, I would only be testing vehicles from the following model year, e.g., 2021. Our guest this week, a 2020 Land Rover Defender 110 P400 SE, is about six months late to my party due to delays in production, trans-ocean logistics and overland delivery. The new Defender can climb a wall but it can't get over Covid-19.

title: Dow Industrials Edge Higher as Unemployment Claims Drop
summary: Investors are looking ahead to Friday's monthly jobs report for clues about the pace of the recovery. The Dow Jones Industrial Average edged higher Thursday as weekly jobless claims declined and investors looked ahead to Friday's monthly jobs report.

title: Snowflake's Cloud is Particularly Dense
summary: Fast-growing company's business model makes forecasting a challenge and nosebleed valuation risky. The beauty of a snowflake is that each one is unique. For Snowflake the company, that also will prove to be a challenge.

title: Luminar Rises in Market Debut, Making 25-Year-Old Founder a Billionaire
summary: Austin Russell started the maker of sensor tech for self-driving cars when he was 17. Today, it went public via a SPAC. Luminar Technologies Inc., which produces sensor technology for self-driving cars, started trading publicly Thursday and made its 25-year-old founder and chief executive a billionaire.

title: Can Biden Bring Unity, Restrain Far Left?
summary: To reunite America, we must return to legitimate governing that respects our system and the laws as they exist.. William Galston's recommendations to Joe Biden ("Biden's Tough Job: Uniting Americans," Politics & Ideas, Nov. 18) offer several areas of compromise and a more thoughtful approach to governing, but like many similar polemics, fall short by their limited scope.

title: What Do We Expect From Our Corporations?
summary: Andrew Abela says that success of a corporation "cannot be reduced solely to profitability." And why not?. In "Woke Capitalism in a Secular World" (Houses of Worship, Nov. 27), Andrew Abela says that success of a corporation "cannot be reduced solely to profitability." And why not? Mr. Abela claims that corporations should be driven by "principles" derived from faith or "some other lasting, existential commitment" instead of the latest progressive causes. But the principles of faith, at least as understood in 2020 America, are subjective, subject to shifting social mores and the differing beliefs of individual corporate executives. Profitability has the benefit of being more objective while, as any student of Milton Friedman knows, providing the most social utility.

title: What's Wrong With Accurate Voter Rolls?
summary: Ohio has done the right thing in cleaning up its voter rolls as an effective method of ensuring fair and honest elections for all its citizens.. Jana Morgan's letter "H.R. 1 Will Make America More Democratic" (Nov. 25) is typical of progressives' demonization of those who disagree with their plans to corrupt election protocol. She accuses Kimberley Strassel of making a partisan attack on "any effort to improve our election system" ("Harvesting the 2020 Election," Potomac Watch, Nov. 13). Ms. Morgan has made the classic error of conflating any attempt to criticize her pet bill with resisting any attempt at reform. She has the gall to criticize Ohio's "purge" of its voter rolls. Shortly after voter rolls were updated there, Ohio voting patterns moved in a conservative direction. After the mess of this Nov. 3 election in Democratic-controlled states, I must conclude that the progressives' desire to "count every vote" really means "count every vote that lands in a ballot box" regardless of its chain of custody or the legality of its arrival there. Ohio has done the right thing in cleaning up its voter rolls as an effective method of ensuring fair and honest elections for all its citizens.

title: Yes, Cheers for Dow 30,000 but Consider the Debit Side
summary: What happens when all this forward spending ceases or, heaven forbid, has to be paid back?. Your editorial "The Dow Hits 30,000" (Nov. 25) notes that since the 2016 election the Dow has increased from 18,000. Before we celebrate too much, should we consider that in that same period total public debt has increased from $18 trillion to $27 trillion (a 50% increase) while America's corporate debt is approaching $11 trillion and consumer debt rose to over $14 trillion through the first quarter of 2020? Is this just a case of the debits equaling the credits? What happens when all this forward spending ceases or, heaven forbid, has to be paid back? What happens to the Dow Jones Industrial average then?

title: Second Covid-19 Wave Looms Over New York City, de Blasio Says
summary: Mayor says a fresh outbreak is nearly upon the city as local health officials prepare to receive 460,000 doses of Covid-19 vaccine this month. Mayor Bill de Blasio warned that a second wave of the coronavirus pandemic is closing in on New York City, as officials prepare to accept enough vaccines this month to begin inoculating more than 460,000 people.

title: Egypt Frees Human Rights Advocates After International Pressure
summary: Arrest of prominent human rights defenders raised tensions with incoming administration of Joe Biden. Egyptian authorities released three prominent human rights advocates on bail Thursday following weeks of international pressure to free them.

title: Connect Four (Friday Crossword, December 4)
U.S. Coal Industry Sends Two More Producers to Bankruptcy
summary: White Stallion Energy and Lighthouse Resources filed for chapter 11 as Covid-19 has exacerbated the downturn in coal markets. Falling demand for U.S. coal during the coronavirus pandemic continues to take a heavy financial toll on the industry, tipping two more coal production companies into bankruptcy.

title: Wisconsin's High Court Turns Away Trump Suit Challenging Election
summary: Setback is latest for president's campaign as deadline approaches for states to finalize results. Wisconsin's highest court dealt another setback to President Trump's efforts to overturn his defeat to President-elect Joe Biden, turning away a lawsuit challenging the validity of hundreds of thousands of mail-in ballots cast in the battleground state.

title: Why Wine in Half Bottles Is Big This Holiday Season
summary: Smaller celebrations still demand good wines. Scaled to suit this moment, half bottles offer other benefits, too. Here, our wine columnist's top 5 smaller-format picks.. ARE YOU an optimist or a pessimist by nature? Your feelings about wine in half bottles might offer a clue. Some consider half-bottles a disappointment: They hold only half as much wine. Others see a low-risk means of trying something new. After tasting a trove of wines in tinyish bottles, I think I fall somewhere in between the two types.

title: 'The Prom': Sitting This One Out
summary: The screen adaptation of the recent Broadway musical has a full dance floor of star power but is far from a night to remember.. Seldom does a show-stopper also serve as a show-starter. That's what happens in "The Prom," but it's no cause for celebration, even though this Netflix version of the recent Broadway musical has been equipped with an exceptional cast that includes Meryl Streep, Nicole Kidman and James Corden. For much of its 130-minute running time the production, directed by Ryan Murphy, suffers from excessive self-delight, chronic glee and a surfeit of joyishness, along with splotches of sentimentality, and doesn't start to come alive with unforced energy until one of its stars launches into a song-and-dance number that lasts for four truly delightful minutes.

title: 'Your Honor' Review: Crashing Into a Crime Family
summary: Bryan Cranston stars in a Showtime series about a New Orleans judge whose son is the culprit in a hit-and-run that kills the child of a vicious mobster.. By episode 3 of "Your Honor," Bryan Cranston's beleaguered Judge Michael Desiato is sitting in a New Orleans dive, drinking whiskey and listening to Leonard Cohen-worse, discussing Leonard Cohen with the only other barfly in the place. Do we feel sorry for him? One of the distinguishing characteristics of "Your Honor" is how little sympathy we're meant to feel for anyone, other than the dead being left behind.

title: What to See, Read and Listen to During the Holidays
summary: From Mariah Carey to 'Wonder Woman,' the entertainment season brings with it a host of options to enjoy from home.

title: 'Another Round' Review: Raising a Glass to Its Contents
summary: Mads Mikkelsen stars in a Danish comedy about a group of friends who try to better their lives by tweaking their blood-alcohol levels.. 'Another Round" is the bland English title of a brilliant Danish comedy originally called "Druk." That means drink, or drinking, and it goes more directly to the essence of a story about four friends, all of them middle-aged high-school teachers, who transform their lives with alcohol consumed in the course of a cockeyed pseudo-scientific experiment. Yet drink, drinking or binge-drinking-there's some of that too-can't begin to convey the wild beauty and emotional depth of this film, which stars the great Mads Mikkelsen and was directed by Thomas Vinterberg from a script he wrote with his longtime collaborator Tobias Lindholm. It's also the first feature, as far as I know, to display its characters' real-time blood alcohol levels on screen.

title: 'The Half-Life of Marie Curie' Review: Fallout of an Affair
summary: Arkansas's TheatreSquared offers a well-performed webcast of a play about the Nobel laureate's persecution by the French press for her relationship with a married man.. In spite of all the theater-related traveling I did in the years before the pandemic struck, there are still plenty of drama companies of consequence that I have yet to see. I've been hearing good things about Arkansas's TheatreSquared for some time now, and it was long my plan to see a play there after paying a visit to the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art, which is just 30 miles away and which I also have yet to see. But life kept getting in the way, and the coming of Covid-19 finished the job: I haven't seen a play in a theater, in or out of New York, since March. So when TheatreSquared announced that it would be webcasting a production of Lauren Gunderson's "The Half-Life of Marie Curie" taped in an empty theater, I immediately put it on my schedule.

title: 'Nurses' Review: Essential Workers, Inessential Show
summary: Set in a pre-pandemic Toronto hospital, NBC's series features an appealing cast and a healthy dose of hospital-drama clichés.. Nurses deserve a show called "Nurses," especially right now. Whether they deserve this particular "Nurses" is another story. Still, one can imagine an exhausted health-care worker coming home, grabbing a bite and curling up with the beautiful, beleaguered characters who populate the show's Canadian hospital, where the pre-pandemic, single-payer problems will seem like so many common colds. Can you drift off to sleep while rolling your eyes?

title: Frank Carney, Pizza Hut Co-Founder, Dies at Age 82
summary: Entrepreneur, who had only tried pizza once when he helped launch the chain, later defected to Papa John's. Pizza wasn't a big part of the local diet in Wichita, Kan., in 1958. Frank Carney had tried it only once. Still, he was open to suggestions.

title: AMC Says It Might Go Bankrupt if You Don't Buy Its Stock
summary: The world's largest movie theater chain is aiming to sell enough shares to give it a bridge until the coronavirus vaccine is rolled out. AMC Entertainment Holdings Inc., the world's largest movie theater chain, has launched efforts to sell more than $700 million worth of stock while warning that failing to raise enough liquidity might force the company into bankruptcy.

title: 'Ammonite' Review: Opening Up a Closed Heart
summary: A romance blossoms between an English fossil hunter and her unexpected guest in this film starring Kate Winslet and Saoirse Ronan.. Instead of getting blood from stones, Mary Anning, the English paleontologist played by Kate Winslet in "Ammonite," gets fossils, insights and wisdom. And behind the heroine's stony visage lurks ardor that's unfulfilled until another woman comes into her life. Francis Lee's film, which co-stars Saoirse Ronan, is many things, all of them remarkable: a queer romance that finds passion in austerity; a biopic that strips away most details of Anning's career while honoring its spirit; and a portrait of genius thwarted by gender-a scientist whose lonely existence is sustained by love of learning, even though, as a woman in the mid-19th century, she has achieved only a small fraction of the recognition, let alone fame, that she deserves. (The film, which has been playing in select theaters, is newly available on premium video on demand.)

title: Bestselling Books Week Ended November 28
summary: With data from NPD BookScan.

title: Southwest Outlines Plans for Potential Furloughs Next Year
summary: Furloughs would be a first for Southwest as airlines continue to grapple with the pandemic. Southwest Airlines Co. on Thursday told more than 6,800 employees that their jobs are at risk without concessions from labor unions or more federal aid as the coronavirus pandemic continues to decimate demand for air travel.

title: The Covid Pandemic Produces a Kinder, Gentler Performance Review
summary: "Empathetic leadership" has some companies easing up in evaluations; "You should just be giving a pat on the back to your employees for showing up". Dreading your end-of-year performance review? It might not be the sweat-inducing conversation of years past.

title: Museum Facades Are New York City's Latest Canvas for Art
summary: Exterior walls are seen as the ultimate canvas, particularly for work that challenges norms and speaks to a broad audience. For its latest high-profile exhibit, the Jewish Museum is presenting a large-scale work by Lawrence Weiner, a conceptual artist who uses language as his medium. In this case, Mr. Weiner created a piece that emphasizes our shared humanity, with the phrase, "All the stars in the sky have the same face" displayed boldly in English, Hebrew and Arabic.

title: Tech Tips to Celebrate Holiday Traditions-When Your Family's Far Apart
summary: Faced with Christmas in quarantine, far-flung families are finding ways that their smartphones, tablets and other tech can help them maintain traditions. BEING HOME for the holidays is bound to feel different this year: Nearly 75% of Americans plan to do their best to celebrate with family and friends virtually according to a recent OnePoll survey conducted for Asurion Home+-with 93% of respondents blaming Covid-19.

title: Salesforce's Slack Deal Faces Post-Pandemic Test
summary: Remote working prompted the purchase but led to a premium price, analysts say. Salesforce . com Inc.'s planned purchase of workplace-collaboration software pioneer Slack Technologies Inc. was prompted by the pandemic, but its success will hinge on whether it delivers in the post-lockdown world.

title: Dollar Stores Start Moving Upmarket
summary: Dollar General and Dollar Tree see a bright future in the treasure-hunt shopping experience. Earlier this year, consumable goods like food were what was driving sales growth at dollar stores. Now these discount retailers are raising their sights to higher-margin items such as party goods and home accessories.

title: GOP Worries Over Georgia Senate Races Intensify Ahead of Trump Visit
summary: With control of the Senate in the balance, the president is attacking Georgia Republican leaders and some of his supporters are urging voters to boycott runoff elections. ATLANTA-Georgia's Republican Party is split by infighting ahead of President Trump's first postelection rally in the state on Saturday, as he and his supporters attack top state Republicans and two pro-Trump attorneys call on voters to boycott two crucial Senate runoffs.

title: The Boeing 737 MAX Question Is About Price, Not Sales
summary: Ryanair's decision to buy another 75 units of the plane is good for Boeing, but the deal probably comes at a discount. Everything has its price. Boeing 's chief concern is just how low it needs to be.

title: Covid Shrinks the Labor Market, Pushing Out Women and Baby Boomers
summary: Resume Subscription. Since spring lockdowns were lifted, the demand for workers has snapped back faster than many economists expected. Between April and October the unemployment rate fell by more than half, to 6.9%, undoing more than two-thirds of its initial rise.

title: France Probes 76 Mosques Suspected of 'Islamist Separatism'
summary: Controversial action aims root out what President Macron says is a campaign to foster a parallel society where religious laws take precedence over civil ones. PARIS-France launched investigations into dozens of mosques across the country on Thursday as part of a contentious crackdown on what the government of President Emmanuel Macron considers "Islamist separatism."

summary: A look around Weingut Freiherr von Landenberg.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Cuomo's Political Self-Inoculation
summary: The New York Governor now wants people to take a vaccine he said they should be skeptical of.. James Freeman is away and will return 12/8.

title: Germany's Moselle Region Is Ripe With Deals on Vineyard Estates
summary: Resume Subscription. John and Pam Pfeiffer spent years touring the grand vineyards of France, Italy and Argentina. But when it came time to buy their own, they chose a small winery in Lieser, a town in Germany with half-timbered houses, a fairy tale castle and verdant Riesling vines along the Moselle River.

title: A German Wine Estate Goes Modern and Minimalist
summary: Inside Weingut Cantzheim on the river Saar.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: China Is National Security Threat No. 1
summary: Resisting Beijing's attempt to reshape and dominate the world is the challenge of our generation.. As Director of National Intelligence, I am entrusted with access to more intelligence than any member of the U.S. government other than the president. I oversee the intelligence agencies, and my office produces the President's Daily Brief detailing the threats facing the country. If I could communicate one thing to the American people from this unique vantage point, it is that the People's Republic of China poses the greatest threat to America today, and the greatest threat to democracy and freedom world-wide since World War II.

title: Look Forward to a Biden on the Rhine
summary: Merkel's successor will be a figurehead, but Germany will at least get a credible left-wing opposition.. Remember Germany? It's the largest economy in Europe, an anchor of the European Union and the eurozone, and (theoretically) an important U.S. ally. It's also an industrial powerhouse engaged in a difficult transition to whatever economy will come after manufacturing, and still the fiscal backbone of Europe. And its politics have been frozen in amber for around 15 years.

title: 3M Cuts Jobs After Pandemic Dents Sales
summary: Surging demand for conglomerate's N95 masks has been offset by lower sales to offices, dentists. 3M Co. said it plans to cut 2,900 jobs to reflect slumping demand for some of its products during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: The Clock Paradox of Quantum Physics
summary: How does an unstable nucleus 'know' when it's time to decay? The answer may lie in the fabric of space itself.. Nobel Prize-winning physicist Frank Wilczek explores the secrets of the cosmos. Read previous columns here.

title: Biden Names Former Obama Adviser to Lead Economic Council
summary: Brian Deese helped oversee the 2009 federal rescue of General Motors and Chrysler and helped negotiate the Paris climate accord. WASHINGTON-President-elect Joe Biden appointed Brian Deese, who was an economic adviser to President Barack Obama, to serve as the director of the National Economic Council in the latest addition to his economic team.

title: Covid-19 Vaccines Are 'Liquid Gold' to Organized Crime, Interpol Says
summary: Police group says organized crime groups may attempt to fake or steal supplies of new Covid-19 vaccines. Criminal gangs will likely attempt to get their hands on the new Covid-19 vaccines, international police organization Interpol warned, potentially disrupting supplies of the crucial shots as they become available.

title: Chevron Slashes Spending Plans as Coronavirus Hammers Oil Demand
summary: U.S. oil company follows rival Exxon in cutting annual outlays amid the pandemic. Chevron Corp. said it would cut its annual capital spending budget by 26% next year and sharply through the middle of the decade, as the coronavirus pandemic forces an industrywide reappraisal of fossil-fuel investment.

title: In South Africa's Wine Capital, a House That Soaks Up Its Surroundings
summary: Resume Subscription. Grape growers in South Africa's wine country are blessed with a strong southeasterly wind blowing off the Atlantic during the growing season. The dry wind, known as the Cape Doctor because of its supposed healing properties, is credited with keeping grapes free of mold and pests, but it can be a challenge to homeowners.

title: Holiday Dressing for a Very Weird Festive Season
summary: When you're more likely to Zoom than party, what kind of gay apparel should you don? Here, Yuletide looks for three types of merrymakers-and a chic Scrooge, too.. KATIE FINNEGAN'S December is usually packed with parties, but this year the reveling will be more concentrated. After her family Thanksgiving was canceled, Ms. Finnegan, 37, a chief customer-experience officer for RiteAid in Los Angeles, will spend the holiday with her parents on Long Island after quarantining. "I see us making a bigger deal out of it than usual," she said. "Everything's riding on those two days-you want to make it more fun." Same goes for her holiday wardrobe. "I'm excited to get something new and to feel special." She's open to both tartan and glitter.

title: Facebook to Remove Covid-19 Vaccine Misinformation
summary: The company is pushing back against claims it isn't doing enough to protect its users. Facebook Inc. updated its misinformation policy around the coronavirus crisis to include vaccine-related content, as the company looks to continue its fight against claims that it isn't doing enough to protect its billions of users.

title: Kroger Reports Strong, But Slowing, Sales Growth
summary: Grocer says it has built up inventory to handle high winter demand; shares fall. Sales growth at Kroger Co. slowed during the latest quarter despite people eating mostly at home, illustrating mounting competition among food sellers to reach consumers during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Activity Picks Up At U.S., Asia Services Businesses, While Europe Contracts
summary: Purchasing managers' surveys add to signs economic recovery continues despite Covid's impact. U.S. services businesses, a key driver of economic growth, gained ground for the sixth straight month in November, adding to signs the recovery is continuing.

title: Home Bars That Bring a Little Something to the Party
summary: Five properties for sale with built-in bars, plus where to start if you're considering one of your own. If you're considering adding a bar to your home but don't know where to begin, consider adopting the guiding principles of the standard restaurant bar: utility and storage. Vivian Bencich, founding principal of Square Feet Studio, an architecture and design firm in Atlanta with bar and restaurant clients, suggests thinking about "every linear foot, every linear inch" of your space as potential for both form and function.

title: Those Bogus Bookcases for Zoom Calls Aren't Fooling Anybody
summary: You can put back the books about vampires, sharks and the Kardashians. We know you don't just read about Churchill and Isaac Newton.. When house-bound experts appear on TV interviews via Zoom, they are almost always seated in front of a large bookcase studiously purged of the usual trash. Whether an expert is deploring executive-office overreach or dissecting the baffling enigma of structural unemployment, you will usually see a gargantuan biography of Ulysses S. Grant or Winston Churchill perched over their left shoulder. Slightly to the left you may spot a three-volume history of the Civil War or something with the ancient Roman abbreviation "S.P.Q.R." in the title.

title: Boeing Wins First Big 737 MAX Order Since Grounding
summary: Irish discount airline's deal for 75 MAX jets comes after waves of canceled orders for the jet, which regulators banned from flight for nearly two years. Ryanair Holdings PLC on Thursday said it agreed to buy 75 of Boeing Co. 's 737 MAX jets, a boost for the troubled plane maker following the aircraft's prolonged grounding.

title: Africans Use Cellphones as Covid-19 Financial Lifelines
summary: The coronavirus pandemic has supercharged growth of mobile money-and credit-on the continent. Consumers struggling with Covid-19 shutdowns across sub-Saharan Africa have found a new place to get cash to make ends meet: their cellphones.

title: Many Companies Turn 401(k) Matches Back On
summary: Employers are reversing course as their businesses rebound and a Covid-19 vaccine is on the horizon. More companies that cut the contributions they made to employees' 401(k) retirement plans earlier this year are reversing course as their businesses rebound and a Covid-19 vaccine is on the horizon.

title: Harris Names Senior White House Staff
summary: Vice president-elect announces three women for top roles. Vice President-elect Kamala Harris named three women to her White House senior staff Thursday.

title: Jobless Claims Fall After Recent Upticks
summary: Weekly initial claims fell by 75,000 after two consecutive increases as economy continues to recover from spring coronavirus shutdowns. New applications for unemployment benefits fell last week after a recent jump, an indication that layoffs are easing but remain high as the labor market continues to recover from the effects of the coronavirus pandemic and related restrictions.

title: Why Controlling Deer Is Such a Bear
summary: Homeowners and local governments can't seem to agree on how to manage herds-which often makes problems worse. Let's talk about Bambi, the precious little fawn of film fame that in real life is wreaking havoc on suburban neighborhoods overrun with white-tailed deer.

title: Grunt Style Doesn't Care About Former Boss's Feelings
summary: Military-themed apparel company isn't responding gently to its ousted CEO's lawsuit. Business isn't war, but it isn't a picnic either.

title: Weekend Sailor Turned a Hobby Into a Big Business
summary: Frank Butler founded Catalina Yachts and made it the biggest U.S. maker of fiberglass sailboats; he was 92. In his early 30s, Frank Butler owned a small machine shop in North Hollywood, Calif., making parts for manufacturing companies. Then his hobby took over.

title: Los Angeles Leaders Want to Remove Their Elected Sheriff
summary: National movement for law enforcement change hits a roadblock at sheriffs, who can't be hired and fired like police chiefs. Political leaders in Los Angeles are trying to find a way to oust their sheriff, a signal that calls for changes in law enforcement leadership are moving beyond police chiefs to leaders whose positions are elected and designed to be immune to such pressures.

title: Stripe to Offer Banking Services in Deal With Goldman Sachs, Citigroup
summary: Shopify, a Stripe customer, will begin offering the service to its merchants early next year. Stripe Inc. is teaming up with banks including Goldman Sachs Group Inc. and Citigroup Inc. to offer checking accounts and other business-banking services, the startup's latest attempt to become the internet economy's financial supermarket.

title: Forced to Retire? It Might Not Be as Bad as You Fear
summary: Retirement columnist Glenn Ruffenach also answers a reader's question on Social Security and delayed retirement credits. I was pushed into retirement recently when my company ended up downsizing because of the pandemic. As a result, my wife and I will need to tap our savings sooner than we anticipated and rethink our plans for the next year or two. Any advice about navigating 2021 and beyond?

title: Number Puzzles
Why You'll Want a Simpler Christmas Wreath in 2020
summary: Over-the-top traditional wreaths seem tone-deaf this holiday. After the year we've had, refreshingly stripped-down, natural versions are trending. AS WE LIMP toward the finish line of this year, a traditional wreath-the perfect circle of evergreen leaves with a big red velvet bow-seems out-of-keeping with the turbulence of 2020. Flocked pinecones and glittery globes are positively tone deaf. "In this historic year, we've noticed in ourselves and our clients a renewed appreciation for simple, natural treasures," said Kelsey Ter Meer, principal designer at Heart & Soil Flowers, in Newburgh, N.Y.

title: Dry Ice Demand Swells as Covid-19 Vaccines Prepare for Deployment
summary: Coronavirus shots requiring ultracold temperatures, coupled with holiday food shipments, kick off 'mad scramble' for solid carbon dioxide. Covid-19 vaccines awaiting regulatory approval will require ultracold temperatures for shipping and storage, and makers of dry ice are bracing for a surge in demand.

title: How Harry Styles Became 2020's Biggest Fashion Icon
summary: A recent Vogue photoshoot showing the singer in a full-length frock nearly broke the internet-underscoring the almost unprecedented influence he has over young men's fashion decisions. HARRY STYLES wore a dress. You may well know that already even if you don't follow fashion or music closely. Photos of the British singer in the custom Gucci frock-snapped for the cover of Vogue-swarmed the internet a few weeks ago, sending his brigade of fans into a tizzy. Scads of tweets and online articles recycled the images. And while most of the coverage lauded Mr. Styles for his beguiling, gender-bending outfit, some conservative pundits including Candace Owens predictably wrung their hands, interpreting the hubbub as a death knell for the so-called "manly man." The cover itself was a landmark: Mr. Styles is the first man to grace the cover of Vogue solo. Think of the instantly collectible issue as a coronation of sorts, confirming that the 26-year-old singer is now officially style-royalty.

title: Census Delays Would Prevent Trump Immigrant Exclusion Plan
summary: House panel says internal schedules indicate bureau is scheduled to deliver apportionment figures after Trump leaves office. Census Bureau schedules indicate the agency needs until Jan. 23 to complete the 2020 count and transmit apportionment figures to the president, a House committee said Wednesday.

title: A Rapid Covid Test That's Also Accurate? NFL Says It Has One
summary: The league says it has tested a rapid point-of-care test developed by two biotech companies that can be turned around in 30 minutes with accurate results. The Baltimore Ravens woke up in Pittsburgh on Wednesday morning in need of a Covid-19 test that was both immediate and accurate. Ravens personnel had registered new positives for 10 straight days, causing their game against the Steelers to be rescheduled three times. The teams needed to know quickly and for certain whether it was finally safe to play.

title: The Market Should Worry About 2022, Not 2021
summary: Covid-19 vaccines make it likely that next year's profit expectations will be met. Forecasts for a boom in 2022 are more of a stretch.. Amid a wave of optimism in financial markets, investors can relax about the expected profit rebound in 2021. They might worry more about 2022.

title: Canadian Banks, Led by TD and RBC, Get Boost From Stimulus
summary: Despite economic slowdown from the coronavirus pandemic, Canada's major banks have avoided big loan losses and boosted deposits. TORONTO-Canada's government has opened its fiscal spigot in an effort to prop up an economy reeling from the coronavirus pandemic. Among the biggest beneficiaries: Canadian banks, which have avoided major loan losses and boosted deposits.

title: Early IRA Withdrawals Can Be Penalty-Free
summary: One of the exceptions is getting more use these days, thanks to the pandemic. Here's how it works.. Individual retirement accounts have strict rules for depositing and withdrawing money. But there are exceptions, and one of them is attracting attention these days-"substantially equal periodic payments."

title: France Mourns Former President Valéry Giscard d'Estaing, a Modernizing Force in Europe
summary: Statesman helped develop European Union, influenced centrist leaders who followed. PARIS-France mourned former President Valéry Giscard d'Estaing Thursday, paying tribute to a statesman who helped modernize the country and develop the European Union.

title: CrowdStrike, Splunk, Kroger: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: U.S. stock futures wavered ahead of a full slate of economic data as investors keep an eye on a potential exile for Alibaba and other Chinese stocks. Here's what we are watching as markets kick into gear Thursday.U.S. stock futures were barely changed Thursday after new data showed initial jobless claims fell to 712,000 last week, below the 780,000 mark economists had forecast. Read our full market wrap here.

title: E-Commerce Strength Boosted November Retail Sales
summary: Shoppers spent more on furniture, groceries and hardware compared with a year ago. U.S. retail spending edged higher last month despite the continuing coronavirus pandemic as a surge in online shopping boosted sales, according to data from Mastercard Inc.

title: Tom Ford's Eco-Friendly Watch and the Other Best-Designed Items of December
summary: Puffy furniture, Taryn Simon's new book, and everything else we're obsessed with this month. Harry Winston is best known for serious diamonds, but the jeweler's newest designs express a more playful side. The Winston Kaleidoscope collection features a mix of gemstones, each faceted and shaped, set in symmetrical patterns with barely a trace of the metal settings visible. Here, rubellites, tsavorites, yellow sapphires, turquoise, aquamarines and diamonds form a many-hued medallion, reminiscent of the swirls it's named for. -Jill Newman

title: Tom Ford's Eco-Friendly Watch and The Other Best-Designed Items of December
summary: Puffy furniture, handblown light fixtures, and everything else we're obsessed with this month.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: U.K.'s Covid-19 Vaccine Program to Test Its National Health Service
summary: Covid-19 vaccine rollout will aim to inoculate everyone in the country over 50 in just a few months. LONDON-Britain's authorization of a Covid-19 vaccine, the first in the West, sets in motion an ambitious plan that will test the capabilities of its state-run National Health Service: Inoculate everybody in the country over 50 within months.

title: Sorry, Millennials. Over-40s Are In at Gucci.
summary: Italian fashion house has toned down its pop-culture-infused designs to court older, wealthier shoppers. Two years ago, Gucci emblazoned its clothes with the New York Yankees logo and the face of Bugs Bunny. Now, the Italian fashion house is embracing Princess Diana and Jackie O.

title: Airline Cards Lose Luster as Coronavirus Persists
summary: The cards have for years helped attract big-spending customers, but their perks are less compelling in a global pandemic. Kimberley Moore called JPMorgan Chase & Co. in October to ask if it would lower the $450 annual fee on her United Airlines Holdings Inc. credit card. A United cardholder for roughly 15 years, Ms. Moore traveled often. Then the coronavirus pandemic hit and Ms. Moore, 53 years old, scaled back her spending and canceled travel plans.

title: Covid-19 Disbelief Challenges Health-Care Workers
summary: Doctors and nurses worry that community skepticism about coronavirus will hurt efforts to limit it. Dr. Michaela Schulte works overnight shifts at St. Luke's Health System hospitals near Boise, Idaho, treating some of the hundreds of critically ill Covid-19 patients filling hospital beds in her state during the most severe period of the pandemic so far.

title: Ahead of U.S. Audit Bill, Chinese Companies Are Finding Their Way Home
summary: Legislation awaiting president's signature would ban trading in shares of U.S.-listed foreign companies that don't allow inspection of papers. HONG KONG-New legislation that is likely to force some Chinese companies off U.S. exchanges will accelerate a migration under way since last year.

title: Hong Kong Media Baron Lai Denied Bail in Fraud Case
summary: Decision comes a day after three activists, including Joshua Wong, were given prison sentences. HONG KONG--Media mogul Jimmy Lai faces months in jail after a Hong Kong court on Thursday denied him bail while awaiting trial on a fraud charge, the latest in a procession of China critics to be put behind bars.

title: E-Commerce Surge Spawns $2 Billion Warehouse Deal
summary: Stockbridge, Korean partner acquire 23 properties across U.S. as coronavirus pandemic drives demand for distribution facilities.

title: Etsy Can Stay Healthy Without Masks
summary: Platform's design could help company stay in limelight after Covid-19 pandemic subsides. Etsy seems to have cornered 2020's key fashion accessory.

title: Covid-19 Vaccine Contest Isn't Over
summary: Pfizer and Moderna might be first past the finish line with vaccines, but others could still grab market share. The race to develop the first Covid-19 vaccines has been decided. The battle for market share is just beginning.

title: An Unexpected Title Challenge at Tottenham, Starring José Mourinho as Himself
summary: A season poised for disaster instead has Spurs at the top of the league ahead of the North London Derby against rival Arsenal. Early in his tenure as manager of Tottenham Hotspur, José Mourinho sat down the most lethal English striker of his generation to tell him he wasn't famous enough. The problem, he lectured Harry Kane, was that people didn't believe the sport's truly elite players belonged at a club like Spurs, in a league like England's.

title: U.S. Audit Watchdog Could Ramp Up Oversight Under New SEC Leadership
summary: Changes at the top of the SEC don't automatically trigger management turnover at the PCAOB, but the securities regulator can wield influence over its agenda. New leadership at the Securities and Exchange Commission is expected to spur increased oversight of public-company audits, according to former regulators and auditors.

title: Health-Care Industry Faces Greater Scrutiny Around Payments to Doctors to Promote Products
summary: A special fraud alert by Health and Human Services casts skepticism on a longstanding industry practice. The health-care industry's longstanding practice of paying doctors to explain and promote products is under review after a government watchdog last month issued a rare warning.

title: U.S. Tech Giants Face Tighter Regulation in Europe
summary: The EU is completing rules on content, competition that are likely to apply to Google, Facebook and Amazon. The European Union plans to introduce in coming weeks new proposals aimed at changing behavior-and, in some cases, business models-at large online platforms, reasserting the bloc's role as global tech cop.

title: Friendly's Owner Hastens Exit From Restaurants With String of Sales
summary: Private-equity firm Sun Capital Partners has all but exited investing in restaurant deals following several bankruptcies over the last decade. The owner of Friendly's and Smokey Bones restaurant chains is accelerating its retreat from the casual-dining business, hastened by a string of bankruptcies among the private-equity firm's portfolio companies and ongoing difficulties in the restaurant industry.

title: California Company's Cell-Grown Chicken Gets Nod From Singapore
summary: Singapore Food Agency deems Eat Just's no-slaughter product safe for human consumptions. California food company Eat Just Inc. won Singapore government approval to sell chicken grown from poultry cells, a step forward for a nascent technology that aims to revolutionize meat production.

title: Delisting Chinese Stocks in the U.S. Won't Sever Their Access to Global Capital
summary: U.S. action against Chinese companies on audit grounds likely won't do the damage that it would have a decade ago. The unanimous vote in the House of Representatives to approve legislation that would likely lead to the delisting of hundreds of Chinese companies trading in the U.S. is a symbolic blow to financial relations between the two countries.

title: Which Schools Leave Parents With the Most College Loan Debt?
summary: Typical families at dozens of institutions are borrowing almost $100,000 to finance student education, new data show. Poor and middle-income parents at hundreds of colleges have taken on substantial debt-amounts sometimes more than twice their annual income-to help their children through school, new federal figures show.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: In China, a #MeToo Case Gets Its Day in Court
summary: Crowds cheered a woman accusing a well-known TV host of sexual misconduct as a Beijing court heard her case. TAIPEI-A woman who filed a sexual-misconduct case against a well-known TV host was cheered by crowds demonstrating their support for her and China's fledgling #MeToo movement as a Beijing court heard her case on Wednesday.

title: Why Black Americans May Face a Slower Recovery from the Recession
summary: Black workers have substantially higher unemployment rates than white workers regardless of their education, data shows. Black workers at every level of educational attainment have substantially higher unemployment rates than white workers, according to Labor Department data. The expanding gap signals Black Americans can expect to have a longer and slower recovery from the 2020 economic recession, regardless of whether they have attended college or not completed high school.

title: Dyal Capital in Merger Talks With Owl Rock Capital
summary: Discussions also involve Altimar Acquisition, an SPAC, and would value combined entity at around $13 billion. Dyal Capital Partners is in talks to merge with Owl Rock Capital Partners LP, part of a complicated deal with a special-purpose acquisition company that would take them public, the firms said Wednesday.

title: Should I Get Tested for Covid-19?
summary: You might have no symptoms of the coronavirus, but there are scenarios when a test is recommended. Covid-19 testing capacity in the U.S. has grown substantially since the beginning of the pandemic, but demand for testing can still outpace the supply many people have access to, especially when case counts are increasing.

title: Coronavirus-Stimulus Efforts Pick Up Speed
summary: Top Democrats say $908 billion bipartisan proposal should be basis of negotiations on new relief bill. Democratic leaders signaled Wednesday they were prepared to reduce their demands for the next round of coronavirus relief, fueling hopes that an agreement could be reached with Republicans by year's end to boost struggling businesses and households.

title: U.S. Bans Cotton Products From Chinese Firm Linked to Alleged Forced Labor
summary: Xinjiang Production and Construction Corps is state-owned paramilitary organization. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration banned imports of cotton products from China's Xinjiang region, saying evidence suggests the products are made with the forced labor of Uighurs.

title: FDA Head Defends Covid-19 Vaccine-Approval Process
summary: Stephen M. Hahn says the agency's vetting will meet the 'gold standard of safety and efficacy'. WASHINGTON-Food and Drug Administration Commissioner Stephen M. Hahn defended his agency's vetting process for Pfizer Inc.'s Covid-19 vaccine, saying a thorough and meticulous review is needed to assure a skeptical public of the vaccine's safety and effectiveness.
